newsitem.title: EGYPT: Oracle sees up to $1 bln Egypt IT market.
newsitem.headline: Oracle sees up to $1 bln Egypt IT market.

text.p: Egypt's market for information technology has the capacity to more than triple in the next five years as population grows and the government privatises, industry executives said on Thursday.
At a news conference to announce the opening of a subsidiary in Egypt, executives from the U.S. software firm Oracle Corp said they forecast the market would grow three to five times.

"Egypt has got the potential in three to five years to have an over $1 billion market in hardware, software and services," Hans Jarnick, Oracle vice president for East and Central Europe, Middle East and Africa told Reuters.
He said that Oracle's market share in Egypt was about $3 million. "We have made a very conscious decision to make a substantial investment in Egypt."

Egyptian businessman Naguib Sawiris, who is working on an import agreement deal with Oracle, told the news conference the current market was about $250 million a year. "It could be $750 million, maybe in the next three to four years," he said.

He said that low government spending on computerisation, and the still-nascent buying power in Egypt as the country continues with economic reform were among the reasons why the figure for the Arab world's most populous country were relatively low.
With $28 billion market capitalisation, Oracle Corp. is the world's second largest software firm after Microsoft.
Oracle plans to open its wholly-owned subsidiary Oracle Egypt Ltd by June, adding to its Middle East presence in the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait, officials said.
They said Oracle is targeting the government, public, private, defence, oil and gas, and banking sectors, and first year operating costs are expected to be $4 million.

Egypt has embarked on a reform programme including privatisation to transform its economy and attract foreign investment. Wilfreid Schoefer, Oracle Near and Middle East managing director, said the reform plans attracted Oracle.

"International companies are now ready to invest in Egypt. It was a logical decision to strengthen involvement and investment," he said. "Egypt is one of the most important information technology markets in the Middle East."
But Sawiris said copyright infringement in Egypt was "a serious point for Oracle, too."
The Business Software Alliance, a lobbying group financed mainly by the big software producers, said in October that it had identified about 100 firms using pirated software in Egypt.
The group said it believed at least 80 percent of software in Egypt is pirated, meaning about $80 million a year in losses.
